name: Wheeler's Oyster Bar
description:
A proper Whitstable institution. Four generations of the Wheeler family have served oysters from this tiny pink-painted cottage on the High Street. No bookings, no fuss — just queue up and wait for a seat at the counter.

The seafood platter is legendary, piled high with oysters, crab, prawns and whatever's fresh that morning. The place is tiny — maybe a dozen seats — so expect to wait, especially on weekends. But that's part of the charm. Bring your own wine (no corkage) and settle in for a proper Whitstable experience.

Don't miss the crab soup if it's on. And yes, the pink paint is deliberate — it's been that colour for as long as anyone can remember.

name: The Whitstable Oyster Company
tagline: Fresh oysters and seafood on the harbour
description:
Sitting right on the harbour in what used to be the old oyster stores, this is the more upmarket option for your Whitstable oyster fix. The building itself is gorgeous — all exposed brick and maritime history — with views across the working harbour.

The restaurant upstairs does proper sit-down meals: fruits de mer towers, grilled fish, excellent chips. Downstairs is more casual. Either way, the oysters are impeccably fresh — they farm their own on beds just offshore.

Booking is essential for dinner, especially in summer. Lunch is easier. The fish pie is a local favourite for those who want something heartier than shellfish.

name: The Lobster Shack
tagline: Casual seafood right by the water
description:
About as casual as seafood gets. You're basically eating off the beach, perched on wooden benches with plastic trays of crab and lobster, watching the boats come in. No pretence, just fresh catch cooked simply.

The lobster rolls are the thing — sweet, fresh meat in a brioche bun with just enough mayo. Or go for the whole crab if you're feeling hands-on. They'll give you the crackers and picks and let you get messy.

Queue at the counter, grab a number, find a spot. Bring layers — it's exposed to the elements. But on a sunny day with a cold beer, there's nowhere better.

name: The Sportsman
description:
Technically in Seasalter, not Whitstable proper, but no local guide is complete without it. This unassuming pub on the marshes has held a Michelin star since 2008 — the food is exceptional, the setting is beautifully bleak, and the vibe is still somehow pubby.

Stephen Harris and his team do things properly: they bake their own bread, churn their own butter, cure their own meats. The slip sole with seaweed butter is legendary. So is the pork belly. The menu changes with what's available, and you eat what they're cooking.

Book well ahead — weeks for weekends, months for special occasions. Worth the wait and the short drive out of town.

name: The Old Neptune
description:
The Neppy. Possibly the most photographed pub in Kent. It sits right on the shingle beach — at high tide the waves lap against the sea wall. Sunsets from here are spectacular.

It's a proper pub: real ales, decent wine list, straightforward food. Fish and chips, burgers, Sunday roasts. Nothing fancy, just solid. The garden (such as it is — it's pebbles) fills up fast on nice days.

Live music most weekends, quiz nights, that sort of thing. Gets absolutely rammed in summer, but out of season it's a lovely spot to watch the weather roll in with a pint by the fire.

name: Pearson's Arms
tagline: Proper gastro pub with sea views
description:
Richard Phillips' gastropub sits on the seafront with big windows looking out to the Isle of Sheppey. The food is a step above standard pub fare — local fish done well, seasonal British dishes, good vegetarian options.

The building was once the Royal Native Oyster Stores office, and they've kept the maritime character while making it warm and welcoming. Upstairs restaurant for dinner, ground floor bar for more casual eating.

Sunday lunch is popular with families. The fish finger sandwich at lunch is surprisingly excellent. Book for dinner, especially weekends.

name: The Ship Centurion
description:
A proper local boozer right in the middle of the High Street. Dark wood, low ceilings, Shepherd Neame ales. This is where you go when you want a pint without the fuss of the fancier places.

They do decent pub grub — nothing revolutionary, just honest food at reasonable prices. The beer garden out back is a sun trap in summer. Quiz night on Wednesdays is surprisingly competitive.

It's the kind of pub where you can strike up a conversation with a stranger at the bar and end up there for hours. Old Whitstable, no nonsense.

name: VC Jones
description:
Three generations of the Jones family have been frying fish on the High Street. There are fancier places, sure, but when locals want proper fish and chips, this is where they come.

The queue snakes out the door on Friday nights. Cod or haddock, battered or breaded, chips cooked in beef dripping. Mushy peas, curry sauce, the works. There's a small seating area but most people take away.

Prices have stayed reasonable despite everything. The fish is always fresh, the portions are generous, and they're fast. A Whitstable institution.

name: Samphire
tagline: Mediterranean small plates and natural wine
description:
A tiny place on the High Street doing Mediterranean-inspired small plates with excellent natural wine. The kind of spot where you end up ordering way more dishes than you intended because everything sounds good.

The menu changes regularly based on what's fresh. Expect things like grilled octopus, burrata with heritage tomatoes, lamb kofta. Vegetarians are well looked after. The wine list is thoughtful — lots of interesting producers you won't find elsewhere.

It's intimate — maybe 20 covers — so book ahead. The vibe is relaxed, the service friendly. Perfect for a long dinner with friends.

name: The Forge
tagline: Proper coffee in a converted forge
description:
Whitstable's best coffee, served in what was once the town's blacksmith's forge. The building's been beautifully converted — exposed brick, original beams, big windows onto the harbour. The espresso machine gets a proper workout.

They roast their own beans and take it seriously without being pretentious about it. Flat whites are excellent. The pastries are baked fresh each morning — the cinnamon buns go fast.

There's a small courtyard out back that catches the afternoon sun. Good for laptop work on quieter mornings, though it gets busy at weekends. No reservations, just turn up and hope.

name: Frank's
description:
Named after the owner's grandad, Frank's does the kind of brunch that keeps you going until dinner. Big plates of eggs however you want them, excellent bacon, proper sourdough. The shakshuka is a favourite.

The coffee's from Assembly in Brixton, well-made by people who know what they're doing. The interior is all white tiles and blonde wood — clean, bright, Instagram-ready but not annoyingly so.

Gets absolutely packed on weekends so arrive early or be prepared to wait. Worth it for the eggs royale. They're also open for lunch — good sandwiches and salads if you want something lighter.

name: Harbour Street Taproom
description:
The craft beer spot on Harbour Street. Twenty taps of rotating beers — local Kent breweries, interesting stuff from further afield, usually a couple of ciders too. The staff know their stuff and can guide you to something you'll like.

It's small and gets lively on weekend evenings. Good place to start a night out or to while away a rainy afternoon. They don't do food but you're welcome to bring in a takeaway or order from nearby places.

The vibe is friendly, the beer is cold, the music is good. What more do you need?

name: Oxford Street Books
description:
A proper bookshop — the kind with teetering piles, unexpected finds, and staff who actually read. Two floors crammed with everything from new releases to rare secondhand treasures. Strong local history section.

The children's section downstairs is excellent, with regular story times and events. Upstairs you'll find fiction, history, nature writing — well curated, with hand-written recommendations throughout.

They'll order anything in within a few days. Support local bookshops and all that. Plus there's a cat who sometimes makes an appearance.

name: Fishslab Gallery
description:
An artist-run gallery in what was once the fish market. The concrete slabs where fish were sold are still there — now they display paintings, sculptures, ceramics by local and regional artists.

Exhibitions change every few weeks. You might find coastal landscapes one month, abstract ceramics the next. The quality is consistently high, the prices often more accessible than London galleries.

Free to browse, friendly staff. Worth checking what's on before you visit. The building itself is worth seeing — a lovely piece of Whitstable's working harbour heritage.

name: The Cheese Box
tagline: Artisan cheese from around the world
description:
A tiny shop packed with incredible cheese. British farmhouse, French classics, Italian specialities — if it's good, they probably stock it. The staff really know their stuff and will happily guide you through the selection.

They do cheese boards to take to the beach (genius), plus all the accompaniments — crackers, chutneys, olives. The charcuterie is excellent too. Perfect for putting together a picnic hamper.

Prices reflect the quality. Worth it for a proper piece of Montgomery Cheddar or a ripe Epoisses. They'll vacuum pack for the journey home.

name: Windy Corner Stores
description:
A wonderful little grocery that's the antidote to supermarket shopping. Local vegetables, good bread, store cupboard essentials, excellent wine selection. The kind of place where you pop in for milk and leave with three bags.

They champion local producers — Kent cheeses, Romney Marsh lamb, eggs from down the road. The veg boxes are popular. Good for picking up everything you need for a self-catering stay.

Friendly, knowledgeable staff. Proper community shop. The name comes from its position on a notoriously breezy corner — you'll understand when you visit.

name: JoJo's
description:
A favourite for relaxed Mediterranean-style eating, tucked away on Tankerton Road. It's been here for years and the regulars keep coming back for the seafood-heavy tapas menu and excellent value set lunches.

The calamari is some of the best around. The mixed meze plates work brilliantly for sharing. BYOB with no corkage makes it even better value — there's an off licence round the corner.

The room is simple — wooden tables, tiled floor, not much fuss. The food does the talking. Book ahead, especially for weekend dinners.

name: Whitstable Produce Store
tagline: Fresh local produce and pantry goods
description:
Everything you need for a proper home-cooked meal, sourced as locally as possible. Fresh fruit and veg from Kent farms, free-range eggs, local honey, good bread, quality store cupboard stuff.

It's on the High Street in what used to be a butcher's — they've kept the character while filling it with good things to eat. The seasonal produce displays are beautiful. Staff are genuinely helpful.

Prices are fair for the quality. This is where to come when you want ingredients that taste like something, not the watery supermarket alternative.

name: Harbour Market
description:
Every Saturday and Sunday, the harbour fills with stalls selling local produce, crafts, vintage finds, and street food. It's grown from humble beginnings into a proper destination market.

You'll find fresh vegetables, artisan bread, local cheeses, handmade ceramics, vintage clothes — the mix changes week to week depending on who's trading. The food stalls are excellent for lunch.

Arrives early for the best pickings (and parking). It gets busy by mid-morning on sunny days. A lovely way to spend a weekend morning before hitting the beach.

name: Keith's Antiques
description:
Keith has been dealing antiques in Whitstable for decades. His shop on the High Street is a warren of furniture, mirrors, silverware, vintage jewellery, and general curiosities. You could spend an hour in here and not see everything.

Prices are fair, Keith knows his stuff, and he's always up for a chat. The kind of place where you might find a Victorian ship's clock next to a 1970s lamp next to a Georgian tea caddy.

Not for people who like organised shops with clear labelling. Definitely for people who like treasure hunting.

name: The Hardware Store Gallery
description:
A beautiful shop-gallery in a former ironmonger's, showcasing contemporary British craft and design. Ceramics, textiles, prints, jewellery — all carefully selected, all made by hand.

The aesthetic is restrained and lovely: whitewashed walls, original shop fittings, just enough on display to appreciate each piece. Prices reflect the craftsmanship — these aren't souvenirs, they're objects to keep.

Exhibitions change regularly. The ceramics selection is particularly strong. Worth visiting even if you're not buying, though you probably will.

name: East Coast Books
description:
A proper secondhand bookshop right by the harbour. Three floors of used books at sensible prices, with strong sections on maritime history, local interest, and general fiction. The kind of place where you find things you didn't know you wanted.

The building is characterful — narrow stairs, uneven floors, books crammed into every corner. Take your time. There are chairs scattered about for extended browsing.

They buy collections too, so the stock is always changing. Check the bargain boxes outside for cheap reads.

name: Whitstable Brewery Bar
description:
The taproom for Whitstable Brewery, serving their own beers plus guest ales in a converted warehouse space. Industrial-chic done well — exposed brick, barrel tables, fairy lights.

They brew some proper tasty beer. The Native is a solid session bitter; the Pearl of Kent is a good blonde. Always something seasonal on tap. The staff can talk you through what's fresh.

No kitchen but they welcome food from nearby takeaways. Regular events — tap takeovers, live music, that sort of thing. Good for a pint before dinner.

name: Windy Corner Gallery
tagline: Fine art with a coastal flavour
description:
A well-established gallery on that famously breezy corner, showing contemporary paintings and prints with a strong emphasis on coastal and maritime subjects. Not chocolate box art — proper contemporary work.

They represent a mix of established names and emerging artists. Exhibitions change monthly. The quality is high, the framing excellent, and the staff are genuinely knowledgeable about the work.

Prices range from affordable prints to serious investment pieces. They can ship internationally. Worth a look even if you're just browsing.

name: The Neptune's Arms
description:
Not to be confused with the Old Neptune on the beach, this is a proper neighbourhood local back from the seafront. Less touristy, more locals propping up the bar. Real ales, friendly atmosphere, occasional live music.

The garden is surprisingly nice for a town centre pub. Good for an afternoon pint away from the crowds. Pub grub is honest — nothing fancy, nothing offensive.

Darts, pool, sports on telly. A proper pub for proper pub things.

name: Tank Design
description:
Clean-lined homewares and gifts in a beautifully designed shop on Tankerton Road. Scandinavian-influenced aesthetic — lots of natural materials, muted colours, thoughtful design.

They stock a mix of established brands and small makers. Good for contemporary ceramics, candles, textiles, kitchen bits. The kind of shop where everything is beautiful and you want to redecorate your whole house.

Not cheap, but quality. Great for finding gifts that don't look like gifts.

name: The Wall Tavern
description:
A lovely little pub tucked away near Tankerton slopes. It's off the main tourist drag, which keeps it pleasantly local. Good ales, decent wine list, proper pub atmosphere.

The building is old and characterful — low ceilings, wooden beams, the works. Gets cosy in winter with the fire going. Summer is all about the garden.

No food beyond snacks, but you can often order delivery. Quiz nights and occasional live music. A proper local for the Tankerton end of town.

name: Beach Walk Cafe
tagline: Tea and cake with sea views
description:
A traditional seaside cafe on the slopes at Tankerton. Proper cakes, good tea, full English breakfasts. Nothing fancy, just solid seaside caff fare served with a smile.

The location is the thing — perched above the beach with views across the estuary. Perfect for a cuppa after a walk along the slopes. Dogs welcome, children catered for.

It's been here forever and hopefully always will be. Cash preferred. Portion sizes are generous. Try the scones.

name: Cupcake
description:
A darling little cake shop and tea room on Harbour Street. The cupcakes are legendary — moist, generously frosted, and in constantly rotating flavours. The brownies are dangerously good.

They do afternoon tea if you want the full experience — sandwiches, scones, selection of cakes, proper teapot. Book ahead for that. Or just pop in for a cupcake to eat on the beach.

Pink and pretty inside, friendly staff, good coffee too. Perfect for anyone with a sweet tooth. The gluten-free options are genuinely tasty.

name: Elliott's of Whitstable
description:
A proper food and wine shop on the High Street. Carefully selected wines (the owner knows his stuff), local cheeses, charcuterie, oils, vinegars, chocolate — all the good things.

They'll put together hampers and gift boxes. The wine advice is excellent — tell them what you're eating and they'll find you something perfect. Regular tastings too.

Prices reflect the quality. This isn't an everyday shop, but for treats and special occasions it's wonderful. Good for stocking up on things you can't find elsewhere.

name: The Tea Room
description:
A proper old-fashioned tea room, the kind with doilies and china cups and three-tier cake stands. It's unashamedly traditional and all the better for it.

They take their tea seriously — proper leaf tea, dozens of varieties, served in proper pots. The scones are excellent, served with clotted cream and jam. The sandwiches are cucumber-crusts-off correct.

Popular with the older generation and anyone who appreciates doing things properly. A nice change from the trendy coffee places. Booking recommended for afternoon tea.

name: Sea Salt Gallery
description:
A bright gallery space on Harbour Street showcasing coastal-themed art and gifts. Local photographers, printmakers, jewellers — things with a connection to the sea and this stretch of coast.

Good for reasonably priced prints and cards alongside more serious pieces. The jewellery selection is particularly nice — lots of sea glass, shells, coastal motifs done tastefully.

Accessible and welcoming. Not intimidating like some galleries. Nice place to find a genuine Whitstable souvenir that isn't tat.

name: Harbour Books
tagline: Books on boats, fish, and the sea
description:
A specialist bookshop focusing on maritime subjects — sailing, fishing, naval history, marine biology. Small but perfectly formed, with knowledge to match the niche focus.

The owner is a former merchant seaman who knows everything about maritime books. Looking for an obscure navigation manual? They'll find it. Want to know about Whitstable's fishing history? They've got shelves on it.

Not much room to browse, but worth squeezing in if the sea calls to you.

name: The Handmade Bakery
description:
Real bread, made properly — slow fermentation, good flour, proper crust. The sourdough is excellent. The croissants are flaky and buttery. The cinnamon swirls disappear fast.

It's a small operation and things sell out, especially on Saturdays. Get there early for the best selection. They supply a few local restaurants too, which tells you something about the quality.

Also does sandwiches if you want lunch. The sausage roll is a thing of beauty. Proper bakery, proper craft.

name: Wheelers Fish Bar
tagline: Fish and chips by the harbour
description:
Confusingly not connected to Wheeler's Oyster Bar, this is a straightforward chippy down by the harbour. Fresh fish, crispy batter, proper chips. Good for eating on the harbour wall watching the boats.

The fish is landed locally where possible. Classic menu — cod, haddock, plaice, plus sausages and pies for the non-fish-inclined. Decent portions, reasonable prices.

There's always a queue on sunny days but it moves fast. No fuss, just good chips.

name: Salt Coastal Interiors
tagline: Beach house style for your home
description:
Coastal-inspired homewares for people who want their house to feel like a beach cottage. Driftwood mirrors, linen cushions, nautical accessories, lovely ceramics. Tasteful rather than tacky.

Good for gifts — they do nice packaging. The furniture pieces are beautiful if pricey. Worth browsing for inspiration even if you don't buy.

The owners have a good eye — everything is curated rather than crammed in. Nice shop to lose half an hour in.

name: The Whitstable Shop
description:
Your one-stop shop for Whitstable-themed gifts and souvenirs. Postcards, prints, mugs, tea towels, books about the town, local produce. A mix of tat and treasures, but curated with affection.

Good for finding something to take home that actually says Whitstable on it. The local photography prints are nice. They stock work by local artists alongside the standard seaside fare.

Friendly staff, reasonable prices. Support local and all that.

name: Crab & Winkle Restaurant
description:
Named after the historic railway line, this restaurant sits right on the harbour serving modern British seafood. The views are excellent — floor-to-ceiling windows looking out over the working harbour.

The seafood platter is impressive. Individual dishes are refined without being fussy — good ingredients treated with respect. Decent wine list. Service is friendly and knowledgeable.

Pricier than the casual seafood spots but worth it for a proper sit-down meal. Book for dinner, especially weekends.

name: The Royal Native
description:
A champagne and oyster bar on the harbour. Small, elegant, focused — shuck some natives, sip some bubbles, watch the boats. Exactly what it says on the tin.

The oysters are impeccable, sourced from local beds. They serve them simply with the traditional accompaniments. The champagne list is good; so is the wine by the glass.

Not for a full meal — this is aperitif territory. Perfect before dinner elsewhere, or just as a treat in itself. Reservations useful but not essential.

name: Whitstable Florist
description:
A lovely little florist on the High Street. Beautiful arrangements, locally sourced where possible, and always seasonal. The displays are gorgeous — they have a real eye for colour and texture.

Good for picking up a simple bunch to brighten a holiday rental, or for proper event flowers if you're planning something bigger. They deliver locally.

Friendly and helpful — they'll put together something special if you tell them what you need. Not the cheapest, but the quality shows.

name: Seashells of Whitstable
description:
A treasure trove of vintage bits and collectables. Mid-century furniture, retro kitchenware, vintage clothes, old photographs, random curiosities. The kind of place where you never know what you'll find.

Prices vary wildly — some bargains, some pieces priced for serious collectors. Worth a rummage. The vintage clothing section is particularly good.

The owner is friendly and knowledgeable about everything in the shop. Have a chat, you might learn something.

name: Maria's Hair Salon
description:
A proper local hairdresser that's been serving Whitstable for decades. Maria knows everyone and everyone knows Maria. Walk-ins welcome, appointments preferred.

No fancy treatments or trendy styling — just good, reliable haircuts and colour. Prices are reasonable, the conversation is free. The kind of salon where you end up knowing everyone's business.

Perfect if you need a trim during your stay and don't want to pay tourist prices.

name: The Long Beach
tagline: Pizza and pasta by the sea
description:
Italian food with seaside views. Good wood-fired pizzas, decent pasta, nice salads. Nothing revolutionary, but well executed and reasonably priced. The terrace is great in summer.

Popular with families — kids love the pizzas. The house wine is drinkable. Service can be slow when busy but the staff are friendly.

Good option for a casual evening meal that won't break the bank. No reservations for small groups, just turn up and wait.

name: Whitstable Harbour Fishmarket
description:
Buy fish straight from the boats. The small fishmarket on the harbour sells whatever's been landed that morning — sea bass, sole, mackerel, crab, lobster, whelks. It's about as fresh as fish gets.

Prices are excellent compared to supermarkets. The fishmongers can advise on cooking and will prep fish however you want. Get there early for the best selection.

Real Whitstable, working harbour stuff. Worth a visit even if you're not buying just to see what comes in.

name: Whistlefish Gallery
description:
Part of a small chain but with a good selection of contemporary prints, cards, and gifts. Strong emphasis on coastal and nature themes — perfect for Whitstable.

Reasonably priced prints you can actually afford to put on your wall. Good for cards too — better than the generic stuff. The framing service is handy.

Bright, well-organised shop. Friendly staff. Nice place to find a print of somewhere you've visited that day.

name: David Brown Deli
description:
An old-school deli with fantastic cheeses, cold meats, olives, and all the bits you need for a proper picnic. The ham is sliced to order, the cheese selection is impressive.

They make sandwiches to take away — great for the beach. Good coffee too. The staff are knowledgeable and happy to let you taste before you buy.

Been here for years and hopefully here for many more. A proper food shop for proper food people.

name: Little Oyster
description:
A lovely shop for children's things — clothes from newborn to about age 10, beautiful toys, books, gifts. Everything is carefully selected with an eye for quality and design.

Not cheap, but you're buying things that will last. Good for presents that grandparents approve of. The wooden toys are particularly nice.

Friendly owners who know their stock. They'll gift wrap beautifully. A nice change from the usual high street children's chains.

name: Whitstable Castle
description:
Not actually a castle — it's a Victorian Gothic Revival mansion now owned by the town. The gardens are lovely for a stroll, with views over the sea. Various community events happen here throughout the year.

You can go in for exhibitions and events. The tea room in the grounds is pleasant enough. It's the gardens that are the real draw — especially the walled garden.

Free to visit the gardens. Nice for a wander away from the shops.

name: Rock Salt
description:
A relaxed bistro right on the beach. More accessible than some of the fancier spots, with a menu that changes seasonally but always features good seafood, decent steaks, and vegetarian options that aren't an afterthought.

The location is brilliant — tables looking out over the water. At high tide the sea is practically in the restaurant. Sunset dinners are special.

Reasonable prices for the area. Service is friendly. Book ahead for weekend evenings.
